conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas in state B, analyze the process from state A to state B.
The process from A to B is isobaric (constant pressure), use the ideal gas law to relate temperatures and volumes.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT.
Define variables: P is pressure, V is volume, n is moles, R is ideal gas constant, T is temperature.
Since pressure is constant from A to B, write equations: P_A V_A = nRT_A and P_B V_B = nRT_B.
Set P_A V_A = P_B V_B and nRT_A = nRT_B since P_A = P_B.
Cancel out nR from both sides to get T_A V_A = T_B V_B.
Given values: T_A = 300 K, V_A = 10 L, V_B = 20 L.
Substitute values into equation: 300 x 10 = T_B x 20.
The temperature of the gas in state B is 150 K.
